Measuring Precision between Point Clouds based on Different Parameters Chapter 1 Abstract

Measuring Precision between Point Clouds based on Different Parameters Izaak Cooper 2020-10-02 Chapter 1 Abstract Part of my research for my thesis is analyzing the precision of a point cloud based on the number of ground control points present in a model. The reference model is the model with the most ground control points (this should be the most accurate model). I then compare a test model with less ground control points (less accurate) with the reference model. The way I have been measuring the error between my reference point cloud and my test point cloud has been through a tool that identifies the euclidean distance to the nearest neighbor. Although this tool is useful, I have wondered how much of that Euclidean distance error can be attributed to the X-, Y-, and Z-direction. This is an important subject in my research as the point clouds will be used in bathymetry mapping. In bathymetry mapping, Shifts in the X- and Y- direction would not be as bad as shifts in the Z-direction, which is why I am currently interested in finding how much of the error is in the X-,Y- and Z-direction respectively.

Chapter 2 Introduction The lidR package can be installed from CRAN or Github. the lidR package allows for the plotting and analysis of an .las point cloud file. This file is a collection of 3-D coordinate points. The number of points in an .las photogrammetry file usually has more than a million points. The code shown below allows one to see some information on one of the point clouds used in the project. library(lidR) readLAS("2-18-20-Correct.las") ## class : LAS (v1.2 format 0) ## memory : 1.3 Gb ## extent : 276743.7, 276961.1, 4170109, 4170479 (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax) ## coord. ref. : +proj=utm +zone=12 +datum=WGS84 +units=m +no_defs ## area : 49087.57 m² ## points : 18.71 million points ## density : 381.11 points/m² library(lidR) las <- readLAS("2-18-20-Correct.las") Zdata <- las@data[["Z"]] Xdata <- las@data[["X"]] Ydata <- las@data[["Y"]] boxplot(Zdata) boxplot(Xdata) boxplot(Ydata)
